title: Fake Amazon Order Confirmation
subject: Your Order #A7392-XK Has Shipped - $847.99
body:
Dear Valued Customer,

Your order #A7392-XK for $847.99 (Apple MacBook Air) has been confirmed and shipped.

If you did not place this order, you must cancel immediately to avoid being charged:

>> CLICK HERE TO CANCEL YOUR ORDER <<

You have 24 hours before the charge becomes permanent.

Thank you,
Amazon Customer Service
redFlags: Sender domain is 'amaz0n-ship.com' — uses a zero instead of the letter 'o' and is not amazon.com
Generic greeting 'Dear Valued Customer' instead of your actual name
Creates panic with a large dollar amount you didn't spend
Urgency pressure — '24 hours before charge becomes permanent'
Asks you to click a link instead of directing you to check your Amazon account directly
explanation: This is a classic phishing email. Scammers send fake order confirmations for expensive items hoping you'll panic and click the 'cancel' link. That link leads to a fake website designed to steal your Amazon login credentials and credit card information. Amazon will NEVER send emails from domains other than @amazon.com. If you're worried about an order, go directly to Amazon.com and check your order history.
howToSpot: Always check the sender's email domain carefully. Go directly to the company's website by typing the address in your browser — never click links in unexpected emails.

title: Fake Bank Security Alert
subject: URGENT: Suspicious Activity Detected on Your Account
body:
IMPORTANT SECURITY ALERT

Dear Account Holder,

We detected unusual login activity on your Bank of America account from an unrecognized device in Lagos, Nigeria (IP: 197.210.XX.XX).

Your account has been TEMPORARILY LOCKED for your protection.

To restore access, you must verify your identity within 24 hours:

[VERIFY MY IDENTITY NOW]

Failure to verify will result in permanent account suspension.

Bank of America Security Team
Ref: #SEC-2024-889271
redFlags: Sender domain 'bankofamer1ca-alerts.net' is fake — uses '1' instead of 'i' and wrong domain
Generic 'Dear Account Holder' — your real bank knows your name
Threatening language — 'permanent account suspension'
Creates extreme urgency with a 24-hour deadline
The 'verify' link would lead to a credential-stealing website
explanation: This phishing email impersonates Bank of America to steal your banking login credentials. The fake domain uses a '1' instead of 'i' in 'America' and uses '.net' instead of the real bankofamerica.com. Real banks will NEVER threaten to permanently close your account via email or ask you to click a link to verify your identity. If you're concerned, call the number on the back of your debit card.
howToSpot: Look closely at the sender domain for subtle misspellings. Banks never threaten account closure via email. Call your bank directly using the phone number on your card.

title: Legitimate Costco Renewal Reminder
subject: Your Costco Gold Star Membership Renewal Reminder
body:
Dear Margaret Johnson,

This is a friendly reminder that your Costco Gold Star Membership (ending in 4521) expires on April 30, 2025.

You can renew your membership:
- Online at Costco.com/membership
- At any Costco warehouse
- By calling Member Services at 1-800-774-2678

Your annual membership fee is $65.00.

Thank you for being a valued Costco member since 2018.

Costco Wholesale
Member Services
explanation: This email appears to be legitimate. It comes from the real @costco.com domain, uses your actual name, references specific membership details (ending digits, membership level), provides multiple ways to renew including a phone number you can verify independently, doesn't create artificial urgency, and matches Costco's actual membership pricing. However, it's still best practice to go directly to Costco.com rather than clicking any links.
howToSpot: Legitimate emails typically: use your real name, come from the correct domain, provide multiple contact methods, don't create artificial urgency, and reference specific account details.

title: Fake Geek Squad Auto-Renewal
subject: Auto-Renewal Confirmation - $349.99 Has Been Charged
body:
GEEK SQUAD - BEST BUY
Invoice #GS-2024-997842

Your Geek Squad Total Tech Support plan has been successfully auto-renewed.

Subscription: Geek Squad Total Tech Support
Amount Charged: $349.99
Date: Today
Payment Method: Card ending in ****

This charge will appear on your next statement.

If you did not authorize this renewal or wish to request a FULL REFUND, please call our billing department immediately:

Call: 1-888-555-0199
(Available 24/7)

Geek Squad Support Team
Best Buy Co., Inc.
redFlags: Sent from an @outlook.com address — real Geek Squad uses @bestbuy.com
Vague payment info — 'Card ending in ****' doesn't show actual digits
Wants you to CALL a phone number — scammers use this to get remote access to your computer
High dollar amount designed to cause panic
No links to BestBuy.com account management
explanation: This is the extremely common 'tech support refund' scam. The scammer wants you to call their fake phone number. When you do, they'll claim they need to 'process a refund' and ask you to install remote access software on your computer. They then pretend to transfer too much money and pressure you to 'return' the excess via gift cards or wire transfer. Best Buy and Geek Squad NEVER use Outlook.com email addresses.
howToSpot: Check if the email comes from the company's official domain. Be suspicious when an email wants you to call a phone number rather than log into your account online.

title: Fake Medicare Benefits Update
subject: Action Required: Your New Medicare Card & Benefits
body:
CENTERS FOR MEDICARE & MEDICAID SERVICES

Dear Medicare Beneficiary,

Congress has approved expanded Medicare benefits for 2025, and you may be eligible for:

- New dental and vision coverage (FREE)
- Reduced prescription drug costs
- Monthly grocery allowance of $150
- Free medical equipment and supplies

To receive your new Medicare card with these upgraded benefits, we need to verify your information:

[CLAIM YOUR NEW BENEFITS]

Please have your current Medicare number, Social Security number, and date of birth ready.

Medicare Benefits Enrollment Center
Ref: MCR-2025-NEW
redFlags: Fake domain 'medicare-update-center.org' — real Medicare uses medicare.gov
Too-good-to-be-true benefits like '$150 monthly grocery allowance'
Asks for Medicare number, Social Security number, and date of birth — identity theft goldmine
Generic 'Dear Medicare Beneficiary' instead of your name
Medicare never emails asking you to click links to claim benefits
explanation: This targets seniors specifically by impersonating Medicare. The scammer wants your Medicare number, Social Security number, and personal details to commit medical identity theft and financial fraud. Real Medicare changes come in official mail, not email. Medicare will NEVER email you to ask for personal information or direct you to click a link to enroll in benefits. Always call 1-800-MEDICARE (1-800-633-4227) if you have questions.
howToSpot: Government agencies like Medicare communicate important benefit changes through postal mail, not email. Never provide your Social Security or Medicare number in response to an unsolicited email.

title: Legitimate Doctor's Office Appointment
subject: Appointment Reminder - Dr. Sarah Chen, March 15
body:
Dear Robert,

This is a reminder of your upcoming appointment:

Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen, Internal Medicine
Date: Saturday, March 15, 2025
Time: 10:30 AM
Location: Maple Street Health Clinic, 425 Maple St, Suite 200

Please arrive 15 minutes early. Bring your insurance card and photo ID.

To reschedule or cancel, call us at (555) 234-5678 or log into MyChart.

Maple Street Health Clinic
explanation: This is a legitimate appointment reminder. It uses your first name, references a specific doctor and location, provides a specific date/time, doesn't ask for sensitive information via email, offers phone-based rescheduling, and doesn't include any suspicious links or urgency tactics. This matches the pattern of real medical appointment reminders.
howToSpot: Legitimate reminders reference specific details you'd recognize (doctor's name, location), don't ask for sensitive info, and provide a phone number for follow-up.

title: Fake PayPal Unauthorized Transaction
subject: Unauthorized Transaction Alert - $629.00
body:
PayPal

Unauthorized Transaction Detected

Dear PayPal User,

A payment of $629.00 was sent from your account to:
Recipient: CryptoExchange Ltd.
Transaction ID: PP-7821934

If you did NOT authorize this transaction, you must dispute it immediately or the funds cannot be recovered:

[DISPUTE THIS TRANSACTION]

You have 12 hours to take action.

PayPal Security Team
This is an automated message - do not reply
redFlags: Domain 'paypa1-secure.com' uses '1' instead of 'l' in PayPal
Generic 'Dear PayPal User' — PayPal knows your name
Extreme urgency — '12 hours to take action'
Threatening that 'funds cannot be recovered' to create panic
The dispute link leads to a phishing site
explanation: This impersonates PayPal to steal your login credentials. The domain uses a common trick — replacing the letter 'l' with the number '1'. Real PayPal always addresses you by name, sends from @paypal.com, and would never give you only 12 hours to dispute a transaction. To check your PayPal account, always type paypal.com directly into your browser.
howToSpot: Look for letter/number substitutions in domains (l vs 1, O vs 0). Real payment services use your name and never impose extreme time limits for disputes.

title: Fake Social Security Suspension
subject: Notice: Your Social Security Number Has Been Suspended
body:
SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION
Office of the Inspector General

IMPORTANT NOTICE

Dear Citizen,

We regret to inform you that your Social Security Number (SSN) has been SUSPENDED due to suspicious and illegal activity linked to your account.

Case Number: SSA-OIG-2025-44829

Charges include:
- Identity theft in multiple states
- Money laundering activity
- Outstanding federal tax liens

To avoid immediate arrest and legal action, you must contact our Legal Compliance Department:

Call: 1-877-555-0132 (Press 1 for English)

Failure to respond within 24 hours will result in a federal warrant being issued in your name.

SSA Office of Inspector General
redFlags: Social Security numbers CANNOT be 'suspended' — this is not a real thing
Fake domain 'social-security-admin.com' — real SSA uses ssa.gov
Threatening arrest and legal action — government agencies don't operate this way via email
Extreme pressure tactics with 24-hour deadline
Generic 'Dear Citizen' instead of your name
Lists multiple serious criminal charges to create panic
explanation: This is a government impersonation scam targeting seniors. The SSA will NEVER: (1) suspend your Social Security number, (2) threaten you with arrest via email, (3) demand immediate action under threat of a warrant, or (4) use a .com domain instead of .gov. If you receive anything like this, call the real SSA at 1-800-772-1213. Report these scams to the SSA Inspector General at oig.ssa.gov.
howToSpot: No government agency will threaten arrest via email or phone. Social Security numbers cannot be suspended. All real government emails come from .gov domains.
